data.title: PHILIP SNOWDEN
data.meta_description: In a recent London magazine appears a highly entertaining character sketch of Mr. Philip Snowden, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the ...
data.text:
draws upon a book entitled. 'Philip

Snowden. An Impartial Portrait,'

for his reminiscences.

For thirty-eight years, he writes.

Mr. Snowden has been speaking and

writing in a bitter, argumentative

style. But a sympathetic idealist

lurks beneath the bitter words.

Mr. Snowden's bitterness is due to

the rebellion of a sensitive nature

against human suffering, and of a

logical .mind against the injustices of

an illogical world. s

When 27, he was badly crippled

hy a bicycle accident. Since then he

Sxas been compelled to drag himself

about on two sticks. Only a man

endowed with exceptional courage

and a profound belief in his mission

could have faced the ordeal of public

life with such a handicap.

He looks a grim figure as he

battles his way to his seat in the

House of Commons. Nevertheless

he has none of the personal bit

terness against fate often dis

played by the deformed.

As might be expected, being a

strong character, he suffers, 'badly

from the defects of his qualities. The

idealist is often at fault. His atti

tude during the war is an example.

It may have been idealistic and log

ical, but it -was not practical. His

predictions concerning the peace are

another instance. They proved hope

lessly fallacious. He remarked -* —

Make no mistake about' it. It

will be a 'people's peace!' This

war is not going to be settled as

other wars have been by states

. men whose incompetence or crim

inality made the war. This war

'is not going to be settled in the

secret chambers of diplomacy ;

it is going to be settled by the

democracies of the different coun

aries.

Thene is, however, this to be said.

Age and .experience have made him

less theoretical, and less inclined to

rely on the powers of logic and senti

ment.

'? SIGNIFIED CHANCELLOR.

i On the whole, he has pnn-ed a

. dignified, competent Chancellor of

; the Exchequer. I refer to his tech

: nique, not to liis 'policy, about which

! I make no comment one way or the

' other. His -acute mind has enabled

; him to master the intricate details of

» National finance, and his speeches

; have been lucid and workmanlike.

I ,He did well for England at The

! , Hague in 1929, when, for once in his

; , life, all fci? fellow-countrymen spoke

I well of hirii. Now he has fallen from

[ grace. Ul- Und tax has called fort*1

; a. chorus of operation.

- it is' sa?r; tiSSt he is favoring '

the profiteers and penalising

s ihetr victims, most of whom haw '

no increment in land' values, and ?
